div1.p: Kean comments on the attempt to add Ames to the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 22, 1946
div1.opener:
FROM GEN, J. R. KEAN
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
22 Nov. 1946
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
Here is the case of Dr. Roger Post
Ames as made up for him by his
friend Mr Lambert and his classmate
Dr. W. M. Brumby- They did a good job
and I think Ames would be surprised
if he could read it. I know I am
surprised to find what a villian I
have been, with the aid of a somewhat
liberal amount of misstatement of
facts- I think this has all been worked
up since Dr. Ames's death- The only per-
son with whom I ever discussed Ames's
claims to have been on the Y. F. Roll of
Honor with its medal and pension was
Mrs. Ames and she has made up a very
2
clever case. I think she must have had
the help of a good lawyer- She did not
have however the claim that Ames had
been appointed a member of the Y. F.
Board by Gen. Fitzhugh on my recom-
mendation! That if it had any truth in
it, would have been an excellent argu-
ment- But think how surprised Gen
Lee would have been at the idea that
every officer or soldier who was ordered
to report to him, became ipso facto a
member of his staff and an assistant in
his office- By the same token the enlisted
men Kissenger and others who were order-
ed to report to Major Reed became members
of his Board- It is all tommy sot.

I hope the family got together all right-
It was a great pleasure to see you-
